addAutoIncrement.description: Converts an existing column to be an auto-increment (a.k.a â€˜identity') column.

columnDataType.description: Current data type of the column to make auto-increment

defaultOnNull.description: When using generationType 'BY DEFAULT' then defaultOnNull = true allows the identity to be used if the identity column is referenced, but a value of NULL is specified.

generationType.description: Type of the generation in 'GENERATED %s AS IDENTITY'. ALWAYS | BY DEFAULT

incrementBy.description: Integer value the increment increments at each call

startWith.description: Initial integer value of the increment

addColumn.description: You can typically use the addColumn Change Type when you want to add a new column and deploy it to the table in your database.

addDefaultValue.description: The addDefaultValue Change Type adds a default value to the database definition for the specified column.

columnDataType.description: The current data type of the column for which to add a default value.

columnName.description: The name of the column for which to add a default value.

defaultValue.description: The default value. Either this property or one of the other defaultValue* properties are required.

defaultValueBoolean.description: The attribute that sets the default value for a column of a boolean type.

defaultValueComputed.description: The attribute that sets the default value for a column using a function which returns value of the same type as the column has.

defaultValueConstraintName.description: The attribute that sets a unique name for default constraint used for a specific column. It works only along with any of defaultValue* attributes listed.

defaultValueDate.description: The attribute that sets the default value for a column of a date type. For example: timestamp, datetime, date, and others.

defaultValueNumeric.description: The attribute that sets the default value for a column of a numeric type. For example: integer, bigint, bigdecimal, and others.

defaultValueSequenceNext.description: The attribute that sets value for a specified column by using the value of the existing sequence. With every new input, the next value of the sequence will be taken.

addForeignKeyConstraint.description: Adds a foreign key constraint to an existing column.

baseColumnNames.description: Name of column(s) to place the foreign key constraint on. Comma-separate if multiple

baseTableCatalogName.description: Catalog name of the base table

baseTableName.description: Name of the table containing the column to constraint

baseTableSchemaName.description: Schema name of the base table

constraintName.description: Name of the new foreign key constraint

initiallyDeferred.description: Is the foreign key initially deferred

onDelete.description: ON DELETE functionality. Possible values: 'CASCADE', 'SET NULL', 'SET DEFAULT', 'RESTRICT', 'NO ACTION'

onUpdate.description: ON UPDATE functionality. Possible values: 'CASCADE', 'SET NULL', 'SET DEFAULT', 'RESTRICT', 'NO ACTION'

referencedColumnNames.description: Column(s) the foreign key points to. Comma-separate if multiple

referencedTableCatalogName.description: Schema name of the referenced table

referencedTableName.description: Name of the table the foreign key points to

referencedTableSchemaName.description: Schema name of the referenced table

validate.description: Shall be true if the foreign key should 'ENABLE VALIDATE' set, or false if the foreign key should 'ENABLE NOVALIDATE' set.

addLookupTable.description: Creates a lookup table containing values stored in a column and creates a foreign key to the new table.

constraintName.description: Name of the foreign-key constraint to create between the existing table and the lookup table

existingColumnName.description: Name of the column in the new table to create

existingTableName.description: Name of the table containing the data to extract

newColumnDataType.description: Data type of the new table column

newColumnName.description: Name of the column in the new table to create

newTableName.description: Name of lookup table to create

addNotNullConstraint.description: The addNotNullConstraint Change Type adds a NOT NULL constraint to an existing table.

columnDataType.description: The current data type of the column.

columnName.description: The name of the column for which to add the constraint.

constraintName.description: The created constraint name (if database supports names for NOT NULL constraints).

defaultNullValue.description: The value for which you can set all values that currently equal null in a column. If null values exist and if defaultNullValue is not set, the change will fail.

validate.description: The attribute which is true if the NOT NULL constraint has 'ENABLE VALIDATE' set, or which is false if the NOT NULL constrain has 'ENABLE NOVALIDATE' set.

addPrimaryKey.description: Adds a primary key out of an existing column or set of columns.

columnNames.description: Name of the column(s) to create the primary key on. Comma separated if multiple

validate.description: This is true if the primary key has 'ENABLE VALIDATE' set, or false if the primary key has 'ENABLE NOVALIDATE' set.

addUniqueConstraint.description: Adds a unique constraint to an existing column or set of columns.

columnNames.description: Name of the column(s) to create the unique constraint on. Comma separated if multiple

deferrable.description: True if this constraint is deferrable, False otherwise

disabled.description: True if this constraint is disabled, False otherwise

initiallyDeferred.description: True if this constraint is initially deferred, False otherwise

tablespace.description: 'Tablespace' to create the index in. Corresponds to file group in mssql

validate.description: Should be true if the unique constraint shall 'ENABLE VALIDATE' set, or false if the 'ENABLE NOVALIDATE' shall.

alterSequence.description: Alters properties of an existing sequence.

cycle.description: Can the sequence cycle when it hits the max value?

incrementBy.description: New amount the sequence should increment by

maxValue.description: New maximum value for the sequence

minValue.description: New minimum value for the sequence

ordered.description: Does the sequence need to be guaranteed to be generated in the order of request?

sequenceName.description: Name of the sequence to alter

afterColumn.description: The attribute that allows you to control where in the table column order the new column goes if it is used in an addColumn command. Only one of beforeColumn, afterColumn, or position is allowed. Since 3.1

autoIncrement.description: The auto-increment column. Ignored on databases that do not support the autoincrement/identity functionality.

beforeColumn.description: The attribute that allows you to control where in the table column order the new column goes if it is used in an addColumn command. Only one of beforeColumn, afterColumn, or position is allowed. Since 3.1

computed.description: The attribute which is used if the value in name isn't actually a column name but a function. Since 3.3.0

checkConstraint.description: The attribute that defines whether to validate the defined check constraint.

deferrable.description: The attribute that defines whether constraints are deferrable.

deleteCascade.description: The attribute that sets delete cascade.

initiallyDeferred.description: The attribute that defines whether constraints are initially deferred.

nullable.description: The attribute that defines whether the column is nullable.

primaryKey.description: The attribute that defines whether the column is a primary key.

primaryKeyTablespace.description: The tablespace to use for the defined primary key.

unique.description: The attribute that defines whether a unique clause should be applied.

validateForeignKey.description: The attribute that defines whether to validate the defined foreign key constraint.

validateNullable.description: The attribute that defines whether to validate the defined not null constraint.

validatePrimaryKey.description: The attribute that defines whether to validate the defined primary key constraint.

validateUnique.description: The attribute that defines whether to validate the defined unique constraint.

defaultValueBoolean.description: The default boolean value for column.

defaultValueComputed.description: The default value that is returned from a function or procedure call. This attribute will contain the function to call.

defaultValueDate.description: The default date and time value for column. The value is specified in one of the following forms: YYYY-MM-DD, hh:mm:ss, or YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss.

defaultValueNumeric.description: The default numeric value for column.

descending.description: The boolean attribute which allows you to specify that a column should be used in a descending order in the index if it is used in a createIndex command. Default value is false (in an ascending order) Since 3.4

encoding.description: The name of the encoding (specified in java.nio.Charset javadoc, e.g. "UTF-8") of the CLOB file (specified in valueClobFile) contents.

header.description: Name of the column in the CSV file from which the value for the column will be taken if its different from the column name. Ignored if index is also defined.

incrementBy.description: The value of each step by auto-increment. Ignored on databases that do not support autoincrement/identity functionality.

index.description: Index of the column in the CSV file from which the value for the column will be taken.

position.description: The attribute that allows you to control where in the table column order the new column goes if it is used in an addColumn command. Only one of beforeColumn, afterColumn, or position is allowed. Uses one based index. Since 3.1

remarks.description: A short description of the column (column comment).

startWith.description: The value auto-increment start. Ignored on databases that do not support autoincrement/identity functionality.

value.description: The value for which to set the column. The value will be surrounded by quote marks and nested quote marks will be escaped.

valueBlobFile.description:
The path to a file, whose contents will be written as a BLOB (i.e. chunk of binary data).

The path to the changelog file location must be either absolute or relative. An example of an absolute path is: /usr/local/somefile.dat on Unix or c:\Directory\somefile.dat on Windows.

valueBoolean.description: The boolean value to set the column to. The actual value string inserted will depend on the database implementation.

valueClobFile.description:
The path to a file, whose contents will be written as a CLOB (i.e. chunk of character data).
The path to the changelog file location must be either absolute or relative. An example of an absolute path is: /usr/local/somefile.dat on Unix or c:\Directory\somefile.dat on Windows.

valueComputed.description: The value that is returned from a function or procedure call. This attribute will contain the function to call.

valueDate.description: The date and time value to set the column to. The value is specified in one of the following forms: YYYY-MM-DD, hh:mm:ss, or YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss.

valueNumeric.description: The numeric value to set the column to. The value will not be escaped and will not be nested in quote marks.

valueSequenceCurrent.description: The name of the sequence in which the current value is used.

valueSequenceNext.description: The name of the sequence in which the next value is used.

columns.description:
The column constraint and foreign key information. Setting the defaultValue attribute will specify a default value for the column. Setting the value attribute will set all rows existing to the specified value without modifying the column default.
See Information about the <column> tag section for more information.

createIndex.description: The createIndex Change Type creates an index on an existing column or a set of columns.

clustered.description: The attribute that creates a clustered index.

indexName.description: The name of the index to create.

tablespace.description: The tablespace in which you create the index.

unique.description: The unique values in the index.

createProcedure.description:
The createProcedure Change Type defines the definition for a stored procedure. This Change Type is better to use for creating procedures than the raw SQL command because it will not attempt to strip comments or break up lines.

Often times it is best to use the CREATE OR REPLACE syntax along with setting runOnChange='true' on the enclosing changeset tag. That way if you need to make a change to your procedure, you can change your existing code rather than creating a new REPLACE PROCEDURE call. The advantage to this approach is that it keeps your changelog smaller and allows you to more easily see what has changed in your procedure code through your source control system's diff command.

comments.description: The comments you can specify in the changeset.

encoding.description: The encoding used in the file defined in the `path` attribute

path.description: The file containing the procedure text. Either this attribute or a nested procedure text is required.

procedureName.description: The name of the procedure. It is required if replaceIfExists= true

procedureText.description: The SQL creating the procedure. You need to define either this attribute or the path attribute. The procedureText attribute is not supported in the XML format; however, you can specify the procedure SQL within <createProcedure></<createProcedure> tags. See the XML example.

relativeToChangelogFile.description: Defines whether the file path is relative to the root changelog file rather than to the classpath.

replaceIfExists.description: If the stored procedure defined by procedureName already exits, alter it instead of creating it.

cacheSize.description: Number of values to fetch per query

cycle.description: Can the sequence cycle when it hits the max value?

maxValue.description: The maximum value of the sequence

minValue.description: The minimum value of the sequence

ordered.description: Does the sequence need to be guaranteed to be generated in the order of request?

sequenceName.description: Name of the sequence to create

startValue.description: The first sequence number to be generated.

createTable.description: You can typically use the createTable Change Type when you want to create a table in your changelog file and then deploy it to your database. It can include columns and another values listed in this documentation.

tablespace.description: The name of the tablespace in which the table is created

encoding.description: Encoding used in the file defined in the `path` attribute

fullDefinition.description: Set to true if selectQuery is the entire view definition. False if the CREATE VIEW header should be added.

path.description: Path to file containing view definition

relativeToChangelogFile.description: Whether the file path relative to the root changelog file rather than to the classpath.

viewName.description: Name of the view to create

customChange.description: The customChange type creates a custom Change Type class.

dbms.description: Specifies logical expression of database type(s) on which the change must be applied. Valid database type names are listed on the supported databases page. It can be a comma-separated list of multiple databases or you can also specify that a change is not applicable to a particular database type by prefixing with !. The keywords all and none are also available.

delete.description: Deletes data from an existing table.

dropAllForeignKeyConstraints.description: Drops all foreign key constraints for a table.

baseTableCatalogName.description: Catalog name of the table containing columns constrained by foreign keys

baseTableName.description: Name of the table containing columns constrained by foreign keys

baseTableSchemaName.description: Schema name of the table containing columns constrained by foreign keys

dropColumn.description:
Drops an existing column(s).

To drop a single column, use the simple form of this element where the tableName and columnName are specified as attributes. To drop several columns, specify the tableName as an attribute, and then specify a set of nested <column> tags. If nested <column> tags are present, the columnName attribute will be ignored.

columnName.description: Name of the column to drop, if dropping a single column. Ignored if nested 'column's are defined

dropDefaultValue.description: Removes the database default value for a column.

columnName.description: Name of column to drop the default value from

baseTableName.description: Name of the table containing the column constrained by the foreign key

constraintName.description: Name of the foreign key constraint to drop

dropIndex.description: The dropIndex Change Type drops an existing index on a column.

indexName.description: The name of the index to drop.

columnDataType.description: Current data type of the column

columnName.description: Name of the column to drop the constraint from

dropPrimaryKey.description: The dropPrimaryKey Change Type drops an existing primary key in the table.

constraintName.description: The name of the primary key.

procedureName.description: Name of the stored procedure to drop

sequenceName.description: Name of the sequence to drop

dropTable.description: Drops an existing table from your database.

cascadeConstraints.description: Add the `CASCADE CONSTRAINTS` to the statement

constraintName.description: Name of unique constraint to drop

viewName.description: Name of the view to drop

executeCommand.description: The executeCommand Change Type executes a system command.

value.description: The value of the attribute (for example: '-param')
The value of the attribute (for example: '-param')

executable.description: The name of the executable to run

os.description: The list of operating systems on which to execute the command (taken from the os.name Java system property)

timeout.description: The timeout value for executable to run

insert.description: You can typically use the insert Change Type when you want to add and deploy the specific data or values to the existing table in your database. It can include columns and another attributes listed in this documentation.

loadData.description: Loads data from a CSV file into an existing table when you add it to your changelog.

commentLineStartsWith.description: Lines starting with this are treated as comment and ignored.

encoding.description: Encoding of the CSV file (defaults to UTF-8).

quotchar.description: The quote character for string fields containing the separator character.

relativeToChangelogFile.description: Whether the file path relative to the root changelog file rather than to the classpath.

usePreparedStatements.description: Use prepared statements instead of insert statement strings if the database supports it.

loadUpdateData.description:
Loads or updates data from a CSV file into an existing table. Differs from loadData by issuing a SQL batch that checks for the existence of a record. If found, the record is UPDATEd, else the record is INSERTed. Also, generates DELETE statements for a rollback.

A value of NULL in a cell will be converted to a database NULL rather than the string â€˜NULL'

commentLineStartsWith.description: Lines starting with this are treated as comment and ignored.

encoding.description: Encoding of the CSV file (defaults to UTF-8)

onlyUpdate.description: If true, records with no matching database record should be ignored

primaryKey.description: Comma delimited list of the columns for the primary key

quotchar.description: The quote character for string fields containing the separator character.

relativeToChangelogFile.description: Whether the file path relative to the root changelog file rather than to the classpath.

usePreparedStatements.description: Use prepared statements instead of insert statement strings if the DB supports it.

mergeColumns.description:
The mergeColumns Change Type concatenates the values in two columns and joins them with a string. The Change Type stores the resulting value in a new column.
You can typically use the mergeColumns Change Type when you want to combine the values from two columns into one.

column1Name.description: The name of the column containing the first half of the data

column2Name.description: The name of the column containing the second half of the data

finalColumnName.description: The name of the column to create

finalColumnType.description: The data type of the column to create

joinString.description: The string to place between the values from column1 and column2 (may be empty)

modifyDataType.description: Allows you to modify data types.

modifySql.description: Although Liquibase supports most standard SQL statements with its Change Types, there are times when you need the generated SQL to be different. The following examples show how to change data types or add additional vendor-specific clauses such as ENGINE INNODB to CREATE TABLE statements. Since 1.9

append.description: Adds SQL to the end of the statement.

applyToRollback.description: Defines whether the SQL modification should be applied to rollback statements. The default value is false. Since 2.0

context.description: Specifies the list of Contexts in which to run the SQL modification. If you do not specify any context, every changeset will be applied. Since 2.0

prepend.description: Adds SQL to the beginning of the statement.

regExpReplace.description: Replaces all instances of the regular expression specified.

replace.description: Replaces all instances of the text specified.

output.description: Logs a message and continues execution.

target.description: Target for message. Possible values: STDOUT, STDERR, FATAL, WARN, INFO, DEBUG. Default value: STDERR

preConditions.description: Preconditions are changelog or changeset tags which control the execution of an update based on the state of the database.

changeLogPropertyDefined.description: Checks whether given changelog attribute is present. It fails if the value is not the same as given.

property.description: The name of the property to check. (required)

value.description: The required value for a given property.

changeSetExecuted.description: Defines if the specified changeset has already been executed.

changeLogFile.description: The file name (including classpath relative path) of the changeset. (required)

columnExists.description: Defines if the specified column exists in the database.

schemaName.description: The name of the table's schema.

tableName.description: The name of the column's table. (required)

customPrecondition.description:
Can be created by adding a class that implements the liquibase.precondition.CustomPrecondition interface. Parameters on custom classes are set through reflection based on the <param> sub-tags. Pass parameters as strings to the custom precondition.

The customPrecondition sub-tags:
param - the parameter to pass to the custom precondition.
name - the name of the parameter to set. (required)
value - a string value to set parameter to. (required)

className.description: The name of the custom precondition class. (required)

dbms.description: Defines if the database executed against matches the type specified.

type.description: The type of database expected. Multiple dbms values can be specified using comma-separated values. (required)

foreignKeyConstraintExists.description: Defines if the specified foreign key exists in the database.

foreignKeyName.description: The name of the foreign key. (required)

schemaName.description: The name of the foreign key's schema.

indexExists.description:
Defines if the specified index exists in the database. You can either specify the indexName attribute or tableName and columnName attributes.
Note: There are a few databases where the indexName is not unique, that's why both indexName and tableName can be used.

schemaName.description: The name of the index's schema.

onError.description: Controls what happens if there is an error checking whether the precondition passed or not.

oneOf.description: Halts the execution of the entire changelog (default). HALT can be put outside a changeset (e.g. at the beginning of the changelog).
Skips over the changeset. Execution of the changeset will be attempted again on the next update. Continues with the changelog.
Skips over the changeset but mark it as executed. Continues with the changelog.
Sends a warning and continues executing the changeset / changelog as normal. WARN can be put outside a changeset (e.g. at the beginning of the changelog).

onErrorMessage.description: Provides a custom message to output when preconditions fail. Since 2.0

onFail.description: Controls what happens if the preconditions check fails.

oneOf.description: Halts the execution of the entire changelog (default). HALT can be put outside a changeset (e.g. at the beginning of the changelog).
Skips over the changeset. Execution of the changeset will be attempted again on the next update. Continues with the changelog.
Skips over the changeset but mark it as executed. Continues with the changelog.
Sends a warning and continues executing the changeset / changelog as normal. WARN can be put outside a changeset (e.g. at the beginning of the changelog).

onFailMessage.description: Provides a custom message to output when preconditions fail. Since 2.0

onSqlOutput.description: Controls what to do in the updateSQL mode. Since 1.9.5

oneOf.description: Runs the changeset in the updateSQL mode.
Fails the preCondition in the updateSQL mode.
Ignores the preCondition in the updateSQL mode (default).

primaryKeyExists.description:
Defines if the specified primary key exists in the database.
(tableName or primaryKeyName is required)

primaryKeyName.description: The name of the primary key.

schemaName.description: The name of the primary key's schema.

tableName.description: The name of the table containing primary key.

runningAs.description: Defines if the database user executed under matches the username specified.

username.description: The database user script which is expected to run as. (required)

sequenceExists.description: Defines if the specified sequence exists in the database.

schemaName.description: The name of the sequences' schema.

sqlCheck.description:
Executes an SQL string and checks the returned value. The SQL must return a single row with a single value.

To check a number of rows, use the count SQL function.
To check for ranges of values, perform the check in the SQL and return a value that can be easily compared against.

expectedResult.description: The value to compare the SQL result to. (required)

tableExists.description: Defines if the specified table exists in the database.

schemaName.description: The name of the table's schema.

viewExists.description: Defines if the specified view exists in the database.

schemaName.description: The name of the view's schema.

remarks.description: The comments stored for the table/view/column

newColumnName.description: Name to rename the column to

oldColumnName.description: Name of the existing column to rename

oldSequenceName.description: Name of the sequence to rename

oldTableName.description: Name of the table to rename

newViewName.description: Name to rename the view to

oldViewName.description: Name of the view to rename

setColumnRemarks.description: The setColumnRemarks Change Type sets remarks on a column.

remarks.description: The comment to set on the column
Comment to set on the table

sql.description: It is useful for complex changes that aren't supported through Liquibase's automated Change Types and to work around bugs and limitations of Liquibase. The SQL contained in the <SQL> Change Type can be multi-line.

endDelimiter.description:
Indicates the end of the SQL statement and prevents incomplete SQL statements from being processed when the SQL files contain statements referencing a ; which Liquibase treats as the default end delimiter. You can use the endDelimiter when the changeset contains SQL to create a stored procedure or function that contains the default ; end delimiter to separate the statements inside the procedure.
For more information, see The endDelimiter SQL attribute.

splitStatements.description: Set to false to not have Liquibase split statements on ;'s and GO's. Defaults to true if not set

stripComments.description: Set to true to remove any comments in the SQL before executing, otherwise false.

sqlFile.description: The <sqlFile> Change Type is useful for complex changes that are not supported through Liquibase automated Change Types such as stored procedures. The SQL contained in the <sqlFile> Change Type can be multi-line.

encoding.description: Specifies encoding used in the file defined in the `path` attribute.

endDelimiter.description:
Indicates the end of the SQL statement and prevents incomplete SQL statements from being processed when the SQL files contain statements referencing a ; which Liquibase treats as the default end delimiter. You can use the endDelimiter when the changeset contains SQL to create a stored procedure or function that contains the default ; end delimiter to separate the statements inside the procedure.
For more information, see The endDelimiter SQL attribute.

path.description: Specifies the file path of the SQL file to load.

relativeToChangelogFile.description: Indicates whether the file path is relative to the root changelog file rather than to the classpath.

splitStatements.description: Set to false to not have Liquibase split statements on ;'s and GO's. Defaults to true if not set.

stripComments.description: Set to true to remove any comments in the SQL before executing, otherwise false.

stop.description: Stops Liquibase execution with a message. Mainly useful for debugging and stepping through a changelog

message.description: Message to output when execution stops

tagDatabase.description: The tagDatabase Change Type applies a tag to the database for future update or rollback.

update.description: You can typically use the update Change Type when you want to update a table in your changelog file and then deploy this update to your database. It can include columns and another values listed in this documentation.

where.description: Allows to define the 'where' condition(s) string

value.description:
Value of the attribute.
Note: If not set, then the first valueXXX defined is used in the order they appear.

valueComputed.description: A value that is returned from a function or procedure call. This attribute shall contain the function name to call.

valueDate.description: Date and/or Time value to set the attribute to. The value shall be specified in one of the following forms: "YYYY-MM-DD", "hh:mm:ss" or "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss".

valueSequenceCurrent.description: Name of the sequence which current value is used

valueSequenceNext.description: Name of the sequence which next value is used

databaseChangeLog.description: The root of all Liquibase changes is the changelog file. Liquibase uses a changelog to sequentially list all changes made to your database. Think of it as a ledger. It is a file that contains a record of all your database changes (changesets). Liquibase uses this changelog record to audit your database and execute any changes that are not yet applied to your database.

changeSet.description:
The changeset tag is a unit of change that Liquibase executes on a database and which is used to group database Change Types together. A list of changes created by multiple changesets are tracked in a changelog.

A changeset is uniquely tagged by both an author and an id attributes (author:id), as well as the changelog file path. The id tag is only used as an identifier, it does not direct the order that changes are run and does not have to be an integer. If you do not know or do not want to save the actual author, use a placeholder value such as UNKNOWN. To execute the changeset, you must include both author and id.

author.description: Specifies the creator of the changeset. Required

comment.description: Specifies the description of the changeset. XML comments will provide the same benefit. Future releases of Liquibase may be able to make use of <comment> tag comments to generate documentation.

context.description: Controls whether a changeset is executed depending on runtime settings. Any string can be used for the context name and they are checked case-insensitively.

created.description: Stores dates, versions, or any other string of value without using remarks (comments) attributes. Since 3.5

failOnError.description: Defines whether the migration will fail if an error occurs while executing the changeset. Default value is true.

ignore.description: Ignores the changeset from the execution. Since 3.6

labels.description: Controls whether a changeset is executed depending on runtime settings. Any string can be used for the label name and they are checked case-insensitively.

logicalFilePath.description: Overrides the file name and path when creating the unique identifier of changesets. Required when moving or renaming changelog.

objectQuotingStrategy.description:
Controls how object names are quoted in the generated SQL or used in calls to the database. Different databases do different things to the names of objects. For example, Oracle converts everything to uppercase (unless quoted). There are three possible values. The default value is LEGACY.
LEGACY - the same behavior as in Liquibase 2.0
QUOTE_ALL_OBJECTS - every object gets quoted. For example: person becomes "person".
QUOTE_ONLY_RESERVED_WORDS - reserved keywords and invalid column names are quoted.

runAlways.description: Executes the changeset on every run, even if it has been run before.

runInTransaction.description: Specifies whether the changeset can be ran as a single transaction (if possible). Default value is true.

runOnChange.description: Executes the changeset the first time and each time the changeset has been changed.

runOrder.description: Overrides the order in the changelog from where the changeset with the runOrder="first|last" will be run. It is typically used when you want a changeset to be always executed after everything else but donâ€™t want to keep moving it to the end of the changelog. Setting the runOrder to last will automatically move it in the final changeset order.Since 3.5

validCheckSum.description: Adds a checksum that is considered valid for this changeset, regardless of what is stored in the database. It is primarily used when you need to change a changeset and don't want errors thrown on databases on which it has already been run (not a recommended procedure). Special value "1:any" will match to any checksum and will not execute the changeset on ANY change. Since 1.7

include.description: The <include> tag is used within your master changelog to reference other changelogs.

context.description: Appends a context (using an AND statement) to all contained changesets.

file.description: Name of the file you want to import required.

labels.description: Appends a label to all contained changesets.

relativeToChangelogFile.description: File path relative to the changelog file containing the element rather than to the classpath. Default: false

includeAll.description: The <includeAll> tag allows you to specify a directory that contains multiple changelog files. It is used within your master changelog file to call on the directory and include all .xml files as changelog files, and all .sql files as individual changes.

context.description: Appends a context (using an AND statement) to all contained changesets.

errorIfMissingOrEmpty.description: Controls what happens if the path listed does not exist or is an empty directory. Default: false. If set to true, the update will fail.

filter.description: A class name that allows you to create custom filters.

path.description: Name of the path you want to reference.

relativeToChangelogFile.description: File path relative to the changelog file containing the element rather than to the classpath. Default: false.

resourceComparator.description: A string containing the name of the class you want to use for sorting.

logicalFilePath.description: Overrides the file name and path when creating the unique identifier of changesets. It is required when you want to move or rename changelogs.

objectQuotingStrategy.description:
Controls how object names are quoted in the generated SQL or used in calls to the database. The names of objects are used differently in databases. For example, Oracle converts everything to uppercase (unless quoted). There are three possible values. The default value is LEGACY.
LEGACY - the same behavior as in Liquibase 2.0
QUOTE_ALL_OBJECTS - every object gets quoted. For example: person becomes "person".
QUOTE_ONLY_RESERVED_WORDS - reserved keywords and invalid column names are quoted.

property.description: Liquibase allows a dynamic substitution of properties in your changelog. The tokens to replace in your changelog are described using the ${property-name} syntax.

context.description: Contexts in which the property is valid. Expected as a comma-separated list.

file.description: The name of the file from which the properties should be loaded. It will create a property for all properties in the file. The content of the file must follow the java properties file format.

global.description: Boolean. Defines whether the property is global or limited to the actual DATABASECHANGELOG. It is given as true or false.

name.description: The name of the parameter. Required if file is not set

value.description: The value of the property. Required if file is not set
